repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Three tweaks:
- The pypy3 CI run was using CPython since the condition to set up python was wrong
- Remove the pypy2 CI run, it is not popular enough to justify the resources
- Update the CI caching action to a newer version ~code and add a check if it is used~. The older action was [emitting warnings](https://github.com/cython/cython/actions/runs/5708344400) (scroll down a bit in the central window)~, revert to using the official action instead of a fork of a fork. I added a check if the cache is used, which should help debugging caching issues.~

comment_data.body: I'm not sure this is equivalent. `ccache` works on a per-file basis I think, where as this doesn't seem to (at least as far as I can tell)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -236,11 +232,15 @@ jobs:
             which pip
 
       - name: Compilation Cache
-        uses: hendrikmuhs/ccache-action@v1.2
+        uses: actions/cache@v3

@@ -236,11 +232,15 @@ jobs:
             which pip
 
       - name: Compilation Cache
-        uses: hendrikmuhs/ccache-action@v1.2
+        uses: actions/cache@v3

comment_data.body:
Stopping to test in PyPy2 basically means that we remove support for it already in Cython 3.0. Is that intended? We'll remove all Py2 support in Cython 3.1, whereas Cython 3.0 rather stands as it is now.

If we decide to remove PyPy2 support right now, there's probably more to rip out.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,10 +165,6 @@ jobs:
             env: { STACKLESS: true, PY: 3 }
             extra_hash: "-stackless"
           # Pypy
-          - os: ubuntu-20.04
-            python-version: pypy-2.7
-            backend: c
-            env: { NO_CYTHON_COMPILE: 1 }

comment_data.body: Not sure how exactly the version pins work in github, but `@3` sticks to the latest 3.x version, so I was guessing that `@1.2` would do the same for "1.2.x". That might depend on the versioning scheme of the specific action, thoughâ€¦
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -236,7 +232,7 @@ jobs:
             which pip
 
       - name: Compilation Cache
-        uses: hendrikmuhs/ccache-action@v1.2
+        uses: hendrikmuhs/ccache-action@v1.2.9

comment_data.body: well, many of the warnings are gone so I guess it did something
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -236,7 +232,7 @@ jobs:
             which pip
 
       - name: Compilation Cache
-        uses: hendrikmuhs/ccache-action@v1.2
+        uses: hendrikmuhs/ccache-action@v1.2.9

comment_data.body: The CI has not been testing PyPy2 since the [check is wrong](https://github.com/cython/cython/actions/runs/5708344400/job/15465930990) (note how neither "Setup Python" nor "Setup python 2" are run). So this is more of a admission of failure than a deprecation. With that, I can restore this and make sure the CI run will use PyPy2 if you prefer, although I view any effort to deal with PyPy2 + Cython as a time sink.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,10 +165,6 @@ jobs:
             env: { STACKLESS: true, PY: 3 }
             extra_hash: "-stackless"
           # Pypy
-          - os: ubuntu-20.04
-            python-version: pypy-2.7
-            backend: c
-            env: { NO_CYTHON_COMPILE: 1 }

comment_data.body:
I changed the CI action check fairly recently, so it probably worked before. Removing it entirely now seems a bit of a step.

But I won't argue with you about PyPy support. :) If you say that PyPy2 isn't used enough (at least together with Cython), then I agree that there's not much use in keeping it alive.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,10 +165,6 @@ jobs:
             env: { STACKLESS: true, PY: 3 }
             extra_hash: "-stackless"
           # Pypy
-          - os: ubuntu-20.04
-            python-version: pypy-2.7
-            backend: c
-            env: { NO_CYTHON_COMPILE: 1 }

comment_data.body: Just to be sure, if you re-enable this, what happens? Does it fail? Does it still not use PyPy2? Is it actual work to get this running again?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,10 +165,6 @@ jobs:
             env: { STACKLESS: true, PY: 3 }
             extra_hash: "-stackless"
           # Pypy
-          - os: ubuntu-20.04
-            python-version: pypy-2.7
-            backend: c
-            env: { NO_CYTHON_COMPILE: 1 }

comment_data.body: Restored the run and added logic to use pypy-2.7 in it
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,10 +165,6 @@ jobs:
             env: { STACKLESS: true, PY: 3 }
             extra_hash: "-stackless"
           # Pypy
-          - os: ubuntu-20.04
-            python-version: pypy-2.7
-            backend: c
-            env: { NO_CYTHON_COMPILE: 1 }

comment_data.body: BTW, this discussion got me to [ask on Hacker New](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=36940871) if anyone is using PyPy at all, and the answers so far are not that encouraging (although it has only been a few hours).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -165,10 +165,6 @@ jobs:
             env: { STACKLESS: true, PY: 3 }
             extra_hash: "-stackless"
           # Pypy
-          - os: ubuntu-20.04
-            python-version: pypy-2.7
-            backend: c
-            env: { NO_CYTHON_COMPILE: 1 }

@@ -220,12 +220,12 @@ jobs:
 
       - name: Setup python
         uses: actions/setup-python@v3
-        if: startsWith(matrix.python-version, '3.')
+        if: startsWith(matrix.python-version, '3.') || startsWith(matrix.python-version, 'pypy-3')

@@ -220,12 +220,12 @@ jobs:
 
       - name: Setup python
         uses: actions/setup-python@v3
-        if: startsWith(matrix.python-version, '3.')
+        if: startsWith(matrix.python-version, '3.') || startsWith(matrix.python-version, 'pypy-3')
         with:
           python-version: ${{ matrix.python-version }}
 
       - name: Setup Python2 (Linux)
-        if: matrix.python-version == '2.7' && startsWith(matrix.os, 'ubuntu')
+        if: (matrix.python-version == '2.7' && startsWith(matrix.os, 'ubuntu')) || startsWith(matrix.python-version, 'pypy-2')

commit.message: revert cache action changes, update to 1.2.9 instead

title: Run CI with PyPy3, update caching
